articles.headline: A Restaurant’s Sales Pitch: Know Your Lobster
articles.snippet: Luke’s Lobster illustrates the benefits of vertical integration, letting the restaurant be part of harvesting, processing and cooking of the key ingredient.
articles.abstract: Luke’s Lobster illustrates the benefits of vertical integration, letting the restaurant be part of harvesting, processing and cooking of the key ingredient.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a steamy summer day in New York in 2009 when Luke Holden, an investment banker, had a craving for a lobster roll. Not just any lobster roll, though. He longed for the “fresh off the docks” taste he enjoyed growing up in Cape Elizabeth, Me.

articles.headline: Colombia and FARC Reach Deal to End the Americas’ Longest War
articles.snippet: The country’s largest rebel group and the government said they had finally come to an agreement to end a conflict that had lasted 52 years and claimed some 220,000 lives.
articles.abstract: The country’s largest rebel group and the government said they had finally come to an agreement to end a conflict that had lasted 52 years and claimed some 220,000 lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Colombia’s government and the largest rebel group in the country have reached a deal to end more than 50 years of conflict, the two sides announced Wednesday, paving the way for an end to the longest-running war in the Americas.

articles.headline: Fed, Eager to Show It’s Listening, Welcomes Protesters
articles.snippet: The Fed is trying to find its footing in an era whose challenge is not the strength of inflation, but the weakness of economic growth.
articles.abstract: The Fed is trying to find its footing in an era whose challenge is not the strength of inflation, but the weakness of economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a dozen protesters in green T-shirts showed up two years ago at the Federal Reserve’s annual conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo., they were regarded by many participants as an amusing addition.

articles.headline: Mylan Raised EpiPen’s Price Before the Expected Arrival of a Generic
articles.snippet: Mylan’s price increases for the allergy treatment device highlight a common tactic in the industry: raising prices just before a generic competitor reaches the market.
articles.abstract: Mylan’s price increases for the allergy treatment device highlight a common tactic in the industry: raising prices just before a generic competitor reaches the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2012, the company behind the EpiPen settled a lawsuit by agreeing to allow a generic competitor into the market in 2015, potentially cutting into a big part of its business.

articles.headline: French ‘Burkini’ Bans Provoke Backlash as Armed Police Confront Beachgoers
articles.snippet: Some politicians began backpedaling as an outcry grew on social media over the apparent public humiliation and ostracism of Muslim women dressed in modest attire.
articles.abstract: Some politicians began backpedaling as an outcry grew on social media over the apparent public humiliation and ostracism of Muslim women dressed in modest attire.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Armed police surrounding Muslim women on beaches and ordering them to remove their modest clothes or leave. Calls from onlookers to “go back to where you came from.” Public humiliation and ostracism with echoes of the morals police of theocratic countries like Iran or Saudi Arabia, not a country that sees its values as a paragon of Western freedoms.

articles.headline: A Conflicted Donald Trump Tries a New Tactic: Sticking to the Script
articles.snippet: After months of flailing attempts, Donald J. Trump has begun to recast his message in more structured terms and wrestle with his temptation to go off script.
articles.abstract: After months of flailing attempts, Donald J. Trump has begun to recast his message in more structured terms and wrestle with his temptation to go off script.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of flailing attempts, Donald J. Trump has begun to recast his political message in more structured terms and wrestle with his temptation to go off script, as his campaign seeks to revive his fading candidacy and turn the focus this fall to Hillary Clinton’s honesty and integrity.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Cycling Matches the Pace and Pitches of Tech
articles.snippet: In the highly competitive and communal tech industry, cycling is taking the place of golf as both an individual obsession and a camaraderie builder.
articles.abstract: In the highly competitive and communal tech industry, cycling is taking the place of golf as both an individual obsession and a camaraderie builder.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thinking he needed to take up a “California sport,” Greg Gretsch started cycling in 1988, when he moved to the Bay Area to work in marketing at Apple after graduating from the University of Georgia. He bought a 10-speed road bike and joined a group of other Apple employees for a standing noon ride.

articles.headline: Saudis and Extremism: ‘Both the Arsonists and the Firefighters’
articles.snippet: Critics see Saudi Arabia’s export of a rigid strain of Islam as contributing to terrorism, but the kingdom’s influence depends greatly on local conditions.
articles.abstract: Critics see Saudi Arabia’s export of a rigid strain of Islam as contributing to terrorism, but the kingdom’s influence depends greatly on local conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump do not agree on much, but Saudi Arabia may be an exception. She has deplored Saudi Arabia’s support for “radical schools and mosques around the world that have set too many young people on a path towards extremism.” He has called the Saudis “the world’s biggest funders of terrorism.”

articles.headline: Attack at University in Kabul Shatters a Sense of Freedom
articles.snippet: Men with rifles and grenades put the American University of Afghanistan, an oasis from violence, through an ordeal that lasted nearly 10 hours and claimed 13 lives.
articles.abstract: Men with rifles and grenades put the American University of Afghanistan, an oasis from violence, through an ordeal that lasted nearly 10 hours and claimed 13 lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As cafes, restaurants, and performance centers in Kabul came under attack one after another in recent years, the campus of the American University of Afghanistan remained a rare oasis for some of the country’s brightest young men and women.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal, Mohamad Fahim Abed and Zahra Nader

articles.headline: Relaxing Privacy Vow, WhatsApp Will Share Some Data With Facebook
articles.snippet: The mobile messaging service, which Facebook bought in 2014, says it will disclose users’ phone numbers and analytics data.
articles.abstract: The mobile messaging service, which Facebook bought in 2014, says it will disclose users’ phone numbers and analytics data.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Facebook bought the start-up WhatsApp in 2014, Jan Koum, one of WhatsApp’s founders, declared that the deal would not affect the digital privacy of his mobile messaging service’s millions of users.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Mark Scott
